questions.question_text: Due to a security breach initiated from South America, the Chief Security Officer (CSO) instructed a team to design and implement an appropriate security control to prevent such an attack from reoccurring. The company has sales and consulting teams across the United States that need access to company resources. The security manager implemented a location-based authentication to prevent non-US-based access to the company networks. Three months later, the same incident reoccurred with an attack originating from a country in Asia. Which of the following security design defects could be the cause?

choices.A: The team did not account for the VPN access and did not ensure non-repudiation
choices.B: The company just replaced a firewall that had a DDoS vulnerability
choices.D: The hackers left a backdoor within the company networks that was not cleaned successfully
choices.C: The sales and supports are reusing the same passwords for their personal accounts, such as banking and email

discussion.content: I think it is between D and A, since the first attack was from South America and the other one from Asia, so the backdoor does not exist unless if the attack was from the same place. So I think A is the correct answer

I think it's A only because It only because the first incident came from a different country then the incident that happened 3 months prior. Unless this would be the same attackers. I assume it is a different threat actor with it being a different country involved.
I don't understand why this would be A. I'd say D. A backdoor would bypass authentication altogether, wouldn't it?

comments.content: I'm pretty sure A: WinHelper is indeed correct.

discussion.content:
Should be A
"all of the well-known, standard ports are secure" 

All answers have standard ports except for winHelper

comments.content: I take back my answer, since the system have an internal network IP, then subseven client will not be able to connect to the server (dynamic dns aside). and since Timbuktu is a remote control tool, then it is the best answer for this case.

discussion.content:
27573 is subseven port. answer is 100% A.
https://www.adminsub.net/tcp-udp-port-finder/27573

Timbuktu is discontinued in April 2015 and support ended in
 April 2020.
Agreed, apparently 1417 is the port for timbuktu-srv1
If this is a normal traffic, why are there two RST messages coming to 172.29.0.109?
It's possible that there's a MAC filtering applied on the network and the adversary implanted a rogue device and he had to spoof the MAC address. I think the answer is D

Rogue device mean that there's a trusted set of MAC address table and the present MAC address does not belong to the table, so Rogue is wrong
There's an attack called MAC spoofing, if there was an option of MAC spoofing that'll be the right
I'll go for IP spoofing.

comments.content:
I take my answer back, it's a rogue device xD 
you can't tell if it's IP spoofing
IP spoofing is for something known like the gateway of the router or static assigned machine.

discussion.content:
Given information is not sufficient to go with MAC spoofing(rogue device on the network with same MAC)

So, have to go with partial answer B

A. Dual NIC doesn't automatically mean same MAC addresses. In fact, it almost never does.
B. This is not an example of IP spoofing. This is MAC spoofing.
C. A part of the mac address will be the same, indeed, but not not the entire MAC address.
D. This is the only logical explanation. An attacker may be trying to circumvent a MAC address filter.

What do you guys think?

comments.content: MAC spoofing is a technique for changing a factory-assigned Media Access Control (MAC) Address of a network interface on a networked device. The MAC Address is hard-coded on a network interface controller (NIC) and cannot be changed. However, there are tools which can make an operating system believe that the NIC has the MAC Address of a user’s choosing.
Upvoted. I would also go for D

I can accept either IP Spoofing or MAC spoofing. The same person could have changed their IP address, which would result in two sessions with the different IP Addresses but the same MAC Address. That being said, that would only be true in an environment with static IPs; in an environment with DCHP, this would be somewhat of an expectation.

It’s a bogus question, for sure, but I think you could technically call it IP Address spoofing and get away with it, even though it’s definitely more likely to be MAC Address spoofing.

choices.B: The alert is valid because IP spoofing may be occurring on the network
choices.C: The alert is a false positive; both NICs are of the same brand
choices.A: The alert is a false positive; there is a device with dual NICs
choices.D: The alert is valid because there may be a rogue device on the network

questions.question_text: An organization has two environments: development and production. Development is where applications are developed with unit testing. The development environment has many configuration differences from the production environment. All applications are hosted on virtual machines. Vulnerability scans are performed against all systems before and after any application or configuration changes to any environment. Lately, vulnerability remediation activity has caused production applications to crash and behave unpredictably. Which of the following changes should be made to the current vulnerability management process?

discussion.content: A is staging environment. Similar to production and all testing should be performed in staging before being put into production

While I can see the merit of A as an answer, the question mentioned that the development environment uses only unit testing. Which is below integration, system and user acceptance testing. I'm leaning towards B as an answer as well. Where getting to user acceptance and fuzzing can mitigate the problems described.

comments.content: You do indeed have a point. But, I think I'll go on letter A for this one. The problem statement is that vulnerability remediation caused production to crash and behave unpredictably - while fuzzing and UAT can mitigate some of these problems, there are still lots of configuration differences from the dev to the prod. The application might pass the tests in DEV, but since they have configuration differences, it might still behave differently in PROD.
I'm fairly sure about A. Most development has 3 stages: Development -> Staging -> Production, where Staging is a simulation using actual Production settings and configurations.

choices.B: Refine testing in the development environment to include fuzzing and user acceptance testing so applications are more stable before they migrate to production
choices.A: Create a third environment between development and production that mirrors production and tests all changes before deployment to the users
choices.D: Refine testing in the production environment to include more exhaustive application stability testing while continuing to maintain the robust vulnerability remediation activities
choices.C: Create a second production environment by cloning the virtual machines, and if any stability problems occur, migrate users to the alternate production environment
